thread.title: FFA investigate Western Sydney Wanderers fans over offensive banner at derby
thread.title_full: FFA investigate Western Sydney Wanderers fans over offensive banner at derby

author: Dominic Bossi
title: FFA investigate Western Sydney Wanderers fans over offensive banner at derby
text:
Raiders 2017: Who's in and who's out 
The Raiders have added to their artillery after an impressive 2016. More videos Wanderers finally turn tables on Sky Blues 
A first-half goal to Brendon Santalab proved to be enough for the Western Sydney Wanderers to finally crack Sydney FC after 20 rounds, as the black and red handed the Sky Blues their first loss this season in a 1-0 win. 
"FFA is aware of the unauthorized and totally unacceptable banner that was displayed in the Western Sydney Wanderers area during Saturday night's Sydney Derby at ANZ Stadium," A-League boss Greg O'Rourke said. 
"The discriminatory nature of the 'tifo' has no place in society and will not be tolerated in the A-League. We are working with the club and currently gathering as much information as possible and will deal with the matter when we have all available facts including CCTV footage." Related Content Sydney FC claim referee apologised for costly derby error 
Fairfax Media sought comment from Western Sydney Wanderers in response to the FFA investigation on Sunday. The club declined to comment after the game on Saturday night when notified of the banner by reporters. 
Wanderers supporters took to social media to celebrate the raising of the banner. The club's active fan group, the Red and Black Bloc, posted a photo on their official Twitter account. Advertisement 
It is not the first time the Wanderers' active supporters have raised offensive banners directed at their rivals, with the first occurring in the inaugural derby in October 2012 featuring a homophobic insult suggesting Sydney FC supporters live in a well-known gay sex-on-premise establishment. 
The banner follows allegations of further fan troubles at the derby. Fairfax Media understands the FFA are working with police investigating reports of a brawl between supporters during half-time. Sources suggest a large group of Wanderers supporters entered a public smoking area behind the designated Sydney FC supporters section in the south end of the stadium where a fight erupted. SHARE
